newsitem.title: USA: Port Authority of NY-NJ delays and trims bond sale.
newsitem.headline: Port Authority of NY-NJ delays and trims bond sale.

text.p: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said Thursday it was delaying the sale of airport improvement bonds until April and also had trimmed the offering's size to $920 million from around $1.2 billion.

"We don't know the exact date but we now expect those bonds to be issued in early to mid-April," said a spokesman for the Authority, which runs terminals and transportation. This is the second time the bond sale was delayed.
Initially, the Authority had planned to sell the debt in December, but the transaction was delayed until the first quarter of 1997 due to its complexity.
No explanation for the sale's second delay or for the reduction in the offering's size was immediately available.

The bi-state agency had approved the bonds in November to finance a new international arrivals building at John F. Kennedy Airport in the Borough of Queens in New York City. Lehman Brothers and Citicorp were chosen to lead the underwriters.
